DataElement.preferredName: California Verbal Learning Test, Children's Version Semantic Clustering Z-Score CVLT Z Score Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Provides a short, individually administered assessment of the strategies and processes involved in learning and recall of verbal material. Assessment is made in the context of an everyday event. It measures both recall and recognition of words over a number of trials and has been found to be sensitive to memory deficits resulting from a variety of neurological conditions. It is designed for ages 5 through 16.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: California Verbal Learning Test, Children's Version Semantic Clustering Z-Score
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Provides a short, individually administered assessment of the strategies and processes involved in learning and recall of verbal material. Assessment is made in the context of an everyday event. It measures both recall and recognition of words over a number of trials and has been found to be sensitive to memory deficits resulting from a variety of neurological conditions. It is designed for ages 5 through 16._The tendency to group items according to their semantic category._A method for converting an individual score into a standard form. The z-score indicates how far and in what direction an item deviates from its distribution's mean, expressed in units of standard deviation. Calculation of a z-score requires knowledge about the population's standard deviation and mean.

Concepts.longName: California Verbal Learning Test, Children's Version
Concepts.definition: Provides a short, individually administered assessment of the strategies and processes involved in learning and recall of verbal material. Assessment is made in the context of an everyday event. It measures both recall and recognition of words over a number of trials and has been found to be sensitive to memory deficits resulting from a variety of neurological conditions. It is designed for ages 5 through 16.

Property.preferredDefinition: The tendency to group items according to their semantic category.:A method for converting an individual score into a standard form. The z-score indicates how far and in what direction an item deviates from its distribution's mean, expressed in units of standard deviation. Calculation of a z-score requires knowledge about the population's standard deviation and mean.

Concepts.definition: The tendency to group items according to their semantic category.

A method for converting an individual score into a standard form. The z-score indicates how far and in what direction an item deviates from its distribution's mean, expressed in units of standard deviation. Calculation of a z-score requires knowledge about the population's standard deviation and mean.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Process and results associated with self-reported measures and instruments, surveys, other tools

DataElementConcept.origin: CVLT-C:California Verbal Learning Test-Children's Version. Delis, D., Kramar, J., Kaplan, E., and Ober, B., Pearson Assessments: San Antonio, TX. 1994

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A numerical quantity that indicates how far and in what direction an item deviates from its distribution's mean, expressed in units of standard deviation. Calculation of a z-score requires knowledge about the population's standard deviation and mean.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.
